channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Journalist Says China May Expel Her for Article on Uighurs
item.description: Ursula Gauthier, a French reporter who wrote an article critical China’s treatment of the Uighur minority, must leave before Jan. 1 unless her credentials are renewed.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: U.S. Pours Millions Into Fighting Poachers in South Africa
item.description: The expanding criminal enterprise in South Africa has driven several animal species to near extinction while fueling the growth of international gangs.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON
item.media:description: A rhino that was killed for its horn at Kruger National Park in South Africa in February. The country, which has 80 percent of the world’s rhino population, has been hit particularly hard by illegal poaching, and officials there are trying to crack down on the trade.

item.title: Turkey Moves to Clamp Down on Border, Long a Revolving Door
item.description: Under growing pressure from Europe and the United States, the country has worked to cut off flows of refugees and foreign fighters.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Members of the Turkish Coast Guard seized a raft crowded with migrants trying to reach Greece in December.

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Rich Are Fighting the Superrich Over Britain’s Manicured Lawns
item.description: Conflicts in the upscale neighborhood of Highgate are the consequence of a widening global divide between the über-rich and the rest.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A partial view of Witanhurst, a 25-bedroom house in Highgate said to be the second-biggest residential property in London, after Buckingham Palace.

item.title: Further Talks on Syria Are Planned for January
item.description: Negotiators will try to make progress on a diplomatic road map, which was approved by the Security Council last week, to end the conflict, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Iraqi Forces Fighting for Ramadi Make Their Way Toward City Center
item.description: Soldiers began a fierce assault to wrest the city from the Islamic State on Monday night, and by midday Tuesday had advanced despite heavy resistance, an army commander said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers in northern Ramadi, Iraq, on Monday.

item.title: British Forces Sent to Help Afghans Hold Off Taliban in Helmand
item.description: The besieged district of Sangin, along with others nearby, seemed in danger of totally falling to insurgents after days of heavy fighting.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Yogyakarta Journal: Transgender Muslims Find a Home for Prayer in Indonesia
item.description: Transgender women have few opportunities to worship, as their defiance of strict gender categorization challenges conventional Muslim views about gender.
item.dc:creator: JON EMONT
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Al Fatah Pesantren in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, is the only Muslim academy or madrasa for transgender people in the world, its leader says.

item.title: Apple Pushes Against British Talk of Softening Encryption
item.description: Faced with proposed crackdowns on encrypted communications after terrorist attacks in Paris and California, Apple argued that lawmakers calling for such access do not understand the technical challenges.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: An iPhone6 Plus at the Apple store in London.

item.title: Crash Near New Delhi Airport Leaves 10 Dead
item.description: An aircraft carrying a team of technicians from India’s Border Security Force burst into flames after crashing near an airport boundary wall, killing all on board.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Government Offers Few Answers After Shenzhen Landslide
item.description: The first body was recovered Tuesday from the site of Sunday’s massive landslide in the southern Chinese boomtown of Shenzhen, where some saw the disaster as inevitable.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Excavators continued to search for potential survivors on Tuesday after a landslide buried buildings at an industrial park in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: Number of Migrants Entering Europe in 2015 Passes One Million
item.description: The figures from the International Organization for Migration reflect the largest movement of people on the Continent since World War II.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants, wrapped in thermal blankets, arriving at the Greek island of Lesbos in November.

item.title: Japan Selects New Plan for 2020 Olympic Stadium in Tokyo
item.description: The design, by the Japanese architect Kengo Kuma, is a traditional oval shape with a partial roof that incorporates exposed wooden beams.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:credit: Japan Sport Council, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An illustration shows the design by the architect Kengo Kuma that was chosen on Tuesday as the main stadium to be used in the 2020 Summer Games in Tokyo.

item.title: Sinosphere: Companies in South China See Opportunity in Beijing’s Smog
item.description: Firms have been advertising the attractions of their sun-filled, tree-lined cities in a bid to lure employees from the north.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG
item.media:description: Beijing on Monday, the third day of a four-day red alert for hazardous air pollution.

item.title: Sinosphere: Video Exemplifies Lawyer’s Civil Rights Campaign in China
item.description: A recording by the civil rights lawyer Pu Zhiqiang casts light on a disgraced official’s detention and underscores his activism.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER and VANESSA PIAO

item.title: U.S. Charges 2 With Corruption Linked to Venezuelan Oil Company
item.description: Two businessmen were arrested on federal money-laundering and corruption charges connected to energy contracts with Venezuela’s state-owned oil company.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: A Petróleos de Venezuela filling station in Caracas. United States officials have arrested two men suspected of running a "fraudulent and corrupt scheme" to secure contracts from the company.

item.title: Chinese Rights Lawyer, Pu Zhiqiang, Is Given Suspended Prison Sentence
item.description: The sentence — three years in prison, with a three-year reprieve — means that Mr. Pu will go free, but he will no longer be allowed to practice law.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Signs depicting the human rights lawyer Pu Zhiqiang outside the Chinese liaison office in Hong Kong last week. Mr. Pu was tried on Dec. 14 before a three-judge panel in Beijing.

item.title: Obama Plans Summit on Migrant Crisis
item.description: The president also plans to spend his final year in office working to spur other countries and the private sector to contribute more humanitarian aid, his United Nations ambassador said Monday.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Strife Puts Education at Risk for a Million Children, Unicef Says
item.description: The report said the conflict in the region, where the militant Islamist group Boko Haram has targeted educational institutions, has kept many children out of classes for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: SpaceX Successfully Lands Rocket After Launch of Satellites Into Orbit
item.description: The launch and then landing could become a familiar sight in spaceflight, allowing rockets to be refurbished and reused.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG
